Short version: 77%On the surface, Still Life is just another modern rendition of the Jack the Ripper mythos, told on two timelines. Under it hides one of the most engaging serial murder thrillers ever written for a point ‘n’ click adventure game, completed by a bit cruel, but somewhat realistic puzzles.Long version: I’ll be honest: Still Life is my favourite adventure game. It was developed by Microïds, a French company known for their unique titles, and uses the same gameplay system that was introduced in Benoît Sokal’s Syberia. This system is also its main drawback, since it is designed for very slow play. Everything will seem sluggish, even for this genre: walking speed, dialogues, even the user interface. It’s not as bad as the old FMV adventure games, but it’s up there.On the other hand, all the other areas in game design are almost flawless. The main character, Victoria is a little bit clichéd tough-girl FBI agent stereotype, but she quickly evolves into an interesting character. Throughout the game, she is placed into a lot of neo-gothic scenery that just oozes atmosphere, all to emphasise the urban fantasy theme of the Jack the Ripper style killings she is investigating.The story has another side though: we learn that these killings copy events that already happened in the 1920s in Prague, and Vic’s grandfather (the protagonist of the quasi-prequel, Post Mortem) was involved in them. His segments not only offer insight, but serve as a contrast to Vic’s world with its washed out tone and almost cruel grittiness.The plot may have sort of a fantasy vibe to it, but the gameplay doesn’t. Progressing feels quite natural and realistic, but not without obvious adventure game puzzles like the clock at the morgue or the cookie recipe. Some of them may be a little too cruel, but the reward is always worth it… even if the ending won’t give the satisfaction of closure one may expect– unless they are accustomed to modern French thrillers.

Post Mortem, introduces one of the protagonists, Gus McPherson but playing the prequel is not mandatory to understand what's going on, although it can help in understanding some of the background story. When visiting her father during the holidays, she has a peek into her Grandfather Gus's trunk. He was a PI in the 20's and it seems that one of his last cases bears an eerie similarity to the one Victoria is investigating now. The game allows you to use forensic tools such as dusting for fingerprints, using a revealer spray to show cleaned up blood stains, taking photographs and looking for bits of clothing or hair left on the scene but it's used sparingly. Some of the puzzles definitely require the use of a walkthrough and keep in mind that the game switches protagonists on occasion between Victoria and Gus.

Still Life			* 8/10Still life is a very dense and deep detective point & click adventure, to be considered kind of a sequel to post mortem, as in this chapter we play as Victoria McPherson, FBI Agent and Gus McPherson's niece (the main character from post mortem). We start the game straight with a crime scene and you have to do the classic actions: talk, examine and so on. It's interesting the accurate level of interactions, when you need to use forensic tools. Unfortunately the title is old so it isn't updated or anything. Fortunately I didn't have any bad issue with my laptop (which is quite new: i5, nvidia 840m, win 10 64bit) and I've been able to play without any trouble such as crashes or freezes.+++Pros+++ STORY. Victoria McPherson is an FBI Agent working on a serial killer case. Reading her grandfather's diary (Post Mortem's Gus McPherson) she will realize he worked on a case where a serial killer was operating with the same Modus Operandi as her Serial Killer. You will both control Victoria and (through a sort of flashback) her grandfather trying to solve both their cases. A small note: consider this title as a first chapter of a whole story, which is concluded in the second Still Life. I won't say more to prevent spoilers. CHARACTERS. I loved the characters. Each one with his or her own personality, all their dialogues are so credible, and they're well dubbed, I believe. A cast very well built. GRAPHIC. OK, the game is quite old so it's not a matter of resolution or shaders, but of visual aspect. All the scenarios are so beautiful and fascinating, with desaturated color tone that gives them a very dark aspect and creating an excellent atmosphere. RIDDLES. The game presents a nice variety of riddles that involve the classic interaction between items, a more deep and precise interaction between multiple items, scheme puzzles, lockpicking (very tough one, solutions in the web are wrong as well, I had to improvise in the last section), Verbal clues that hide codes and so on. ---Cons--- Dialogues. when you're talking with someone you can choose with left or right mouse click to talk about the case or generic stuff... You don't get to choose the line parts like in old classic point & click adventure nor you don't see what you're about to say. It's not an important thing since you inevitably end up talking about everything with everyone but I kind of missed this option, as a Classic point & click lover. Resolution. Unfortunately the game has quite the age, you can't change any graphic detail, nor resolution. 4:3. Considering the age the other problem is the aspect ratio. Unfortunately it wasn't studied for 16:9 monitors. Speaking animations. I Have no idea if it's a problem caused by my OS (Win 10), the OS Bit (64bit), the modern hardware (Intel i5 + nVidia 840m) but when characters talk they move their mouth at the speed of light. literally. I can't distinguish the frames, they're super fast...

												Still Life introduces you in a crazy serial killer case that went on for several centuries leaving bloody traces in different parts of the world recently leading to Chicago… You are playing the main character “Vic” who is an FBI Agent leading the investigation of the recent Chicago murders. She soon gets personally involved as her family seems to be connected to the investigation from the past. Here it is going to get really interesting. You are jumping back in time and witness some elaborated places in Prague in the 20’s playing Vic’s granddad who was the former PI in a very similar case. While stranded in the past and finding out how everything started you get interrupted by reality, just as new information comes up for our present investigation. While talking to possible suspects and witnesses, doing usual detective work (including going rogue after an argument with the boss, being suspended and facing the bad guys on your own), you will also discover some brutal murder scenes.You will be presented action scenes, outstanding storytelling and good character development. The gameplay requires some getting used to, especially the use of the inventory. While playing, you can easily miss out on objects, but you do not carry a lot of things at the same time, so putting everything in a useful combination is pretty obvious, but it did not bother me that much. And, like a typical point-and-click game, you also have to solve some puzzles (most people say this is unrealistic and dull, but I always like that most in such kind of games…).At first I thought it would be just a usual point-and-click adventure, but afterwards I would say it is one of the best games I played in a long time. The case you have to investigate is getting under your skin - I seldom played such a thrilling point-and-click adventure. Released in 2005 the graphics are not the finest, but it is still enjoyable. The amount of settings is enormous and I praise that the story kept its mystery elements until the end. The sound acting was really good, even though not always in sync. In contrast to the second part (I have not bought it yet, but it has lots of negative reviews, so…) you cannot do anything wrong with this game - especially if it is on sale.

												Still Life follows the trail of a gruesome serial killer in a classic thriller/mystery style. You play as detective Victoria McPherson who is investigating a string of prosti tute murders, all of whom's bodies were found badly beaten and mutilated. The atmosphere is well done and each crime scene is quite graphic. The style of this game is a classic point and click adventure. As far as game play is concerned, adventure games tend to be vague and it can be difficult to figure out what you are supposed to do next, but that rarely happens in this title. In fact, in Still Life, it is usually very obvious what you are supposed to do - but that's the hard part. The puzzles in this game range from rather simple to frustratingly demanding. While the puzzles do become immensely complex, the puzzles are also very logical. I personally spent about 30-40 minutes trying to figure out one of the difficult puzzles in this game. So if you are going to play this title, you need to have patience and a strong penchant for puzzle solving. 												If you're a fan of classic point-and-click adventure games, you should try Still Life.  The plot revolves around an agent investigating serial murders in Chicago and discovering that her grandfather investigated the same type of murders in Prague decades ago. While the dialogue is pretty campy, the story is amazingly gripping at times and the pre-rendered backgrounds are extremely well done and atmospheric.  Smooth transitions between the Chicago story and Prague keep the game interesting as you uncover clues from the past and present, playing as both Victoria and her grandfather. Nothing can hurt your character but there were a few moments of dread as she searches through some intensely disturbing areas of the game and gets uncomfortably closer to finding the killer. Movement is a bit clunky though and there are times when you feel like you're waiting endlessly for her to reach her destination, even when can run (more like brisk jog). Also, lack of true ending - glad there is 2!

												In an effort to buff up on the different genres of games I've experienced, I bought Still Life during the Summer Steam Sale of 2013. Since it is currently the Autumn Steam Sale I figured I write up a review for those currently looking to buy it.Still Life is a 3D interactive puzzle adventure that follows a single muder mystery case that unfolds from the perspective of two different characters, FBI Agent McPherson (In 2004 US Chicago) and her PI Grandfather Gustav McPherson (In 1920s Czech Rep Prague) . Neither of these two characters interact directly with the other; Gustav McPherson's story is told through diary.In general there's not much difference in gameplay that occurs during a switch of characters as it is mostly done for narritives sake. In terms of gameplay Still Life's is fairly weak. Much of the interaction in the game mainly comes from chosing the correct person to talk to, using the right items/objects and solving a few puzzles. The puzzles themselves are actually very well thought out and surprisingly difficult! I actually found myself at wits end on a puzzle and am ashamed to say that I actually had to find help online!Graphics wise Still Life looks quite dated now a days. A lot of the lip synching when a character speak looks incredible jarring. Mouths on some characters look more like nutcrakers when they talk.... On the flipside character models themselves are well designed and look quite decent too! Where Still Life really shines though is in the Pre renderded enviroments. If you're a fan of early Resident Evil games or like looking at background art in general, you will enjoy the look and immersion of the enviroments that the visual departments in Still Life offers.Though honestly the main reason anyone should really play Still Life would be for its story and characters! Over all I feel like the characterization of everyone in Still Life is done very realisticly. A lot of the dialouge does a very good job explaining the lives and personalities of the people they are suppose to represent. It's been more than a few months since I've played this game and though I can't recall completely by heart all the names of the characters; the use of the voice actors and the roles the characters played in the story themselves are embedded quite well into my mind. Also mild spoiler alert but I have to point this out as it's a slight♥♥♥♥♥♥move on the developers part. The story ends on a cliff hanger! You don't catch your murderer. You have to buy part two to wrap up this case. Because of this I recommend that if you want all of your monies worth that you buy this game when it is on sale. While it is a good game at telling a story and presenting convincing and unique characters, Still Life fails to completely maintain any interesting gameplay. The story doesn't suffer from it but sometimes you feel more like you're watching movie.I recommed this game but only buy it as the part 1&2 bundle and on sale.

												How to even start? I can't recommend this game at all, and I'm writing this review as an outlet for my overwhelming disappointment more than anything else. If it helps you decide about this game: bonus. I understand it's part of a trilogy, but honestly, I played this one first and I'm never going to bother with the other two for the bad taste this one left. Short Version: Don't. The puzzles aren't good and the characters are bad. The story is disappointing and it doesn't end. Not even a little; so no satisfying victory for you.Long Version:If you're into point & click, puzzles, mysteries and crime, this game is going to look like Christmas until you actually start playing it. I picked it up because my gf and I like all of the things it was supposed to be, and it had so many good reviews! Reading over those reviews now, I feel like I must have played a completely different game.If you're still reading, here are some of the reasons I recommend you look elsewhere for whatever it is you're after:Pace - This game is slow even if you play it as quickly as you can. It will not let you do anything out of order or sooner than it thinks you should. You will have solved most of the puzzles before they've started, but often you'll have to talk to a specific person, or look at a specific thing before the main character will go 'oh, I should do blah' and only THEN can we proceed. So really, the puzzle is trying to get to start the puzzle?Puzzles - They're not hard, some of them are tedious, and they're not really story relevant. Also, there aren't very many of them, so it's less of a puzzle game and more of a walk around simulator. There isn't any outside-the-box thinking here and when I say story relevant I mean the puzzles you complete to progress the story don't make sense within the story itself. Which brings me to the third and most serious offenderStory - Dear. God. Okay, so this is the part that broke the game for us. Somewhere in this game is a really interesting story about some disturbed people killing other people all tied together with art and family. It should be awesome, but you don't really get to be a part of that story and the best parts of the game are when you're reading journals and speculating on who the big bad is. One of the characters you play as, Gus, is actually pretty interesting. He takes you along through his section of the mystery and he makes sense as a character. He's a private eye, not a cop, and he does some not exactly legal stuff to get ahead of the killer before more people are hurt. People he loves are being directly impacted, so you get his urgency and interest. We could get behind that; it wasn't always great, but it made enough sense for Prague in the 20's. The other character is Victoria. You're with her most of the game, and she might be the single worst federal agent in the history of terrible representation of the FBI. At the beginning it's not so bad: she clearly has a lot of personality and not a lot of respect for authority, which is a staple for cop characters, fine. But that lack of respect leads her out on a ridiculously elaborate and illegal adventure that should land her in jail except SPOILERS: she off-handedly blackmails her boss. It becomes ridiculous and farcical that she could carry on the way she does and not face criminal charges. She never calls for backup or phones things in (like murders?), she tampers with evidence, leaves key witnesses in the protection of her boyfriend rather than, I dunno, the police? Not only is she not ‘by the book’, she’s never seen it, she is illiterate as far as ‘the book’ is concerned and you have to suspect the only reason she’s in the FBI is because he dad is the DA. She's just awful, and it was a struggle to finish the game with her because everything she did was insane and unrealistic. It kills any suspension of disbelief you might have had and in the end, the only person you feel like you have enough evidence to convict is yourself.This game could have, but didn’t. It has some nice art though, so I guess there’s that.
